Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel for Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at International Conference on Functional Programming 2018 (PLMW@ICFP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW) is being organized as part of the 23rd ACM International Conference on Functional Programming (ICFP) 2018, the premier conference on the design, implementations, principles, and uses of functional programming. The conference will be held in St. Louis, Missouri. This award specifically supports students from underrepresented groups and gives priority to US citizens and permanent residents to attend the mentoring workshop in addition to the ICFP conference. The impact of the award relates to broadening participation in computing, providing opportunities for students to receive mentoring from leading researchers, and building the next generation of researchers and knowledgeable practitioners in programming languages and related topics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at the SIGPLAN
International Conference on Functional Programming was held on Sunday,
September 23 in St. Louis, MO.

The workshop aims to encourage women and underrepresented minorities
to join the programming language research community.  To achieve this
goal, PLMW seeks to attract participants who would not normally attend
ICFP.  This objective guided the selection of speakers and funded
students.

In addition to the $15,000 in funding from the NSF, the workshop was
supported by SIGPLAN ($20K), an anonymous donor ($20K), and Google
($1K).  This money was used solely to provide travel scholarships for
students to attend the one-day mentoring workshop as well as ICFP, a
three-day premier research conference on programming languages and
functional programming.  The conference was co-located with
StrangeLoop, a large industrial programming conference held annually
in St. Louis.

There were 45 attendees, of which 40 were students, and 28 were
supported with financial aid.  Of funded students, 50% reported being
members of underrepresented minorities, 16.67% reported N/A.  36.67%
reported their gender as female, 6.67% as nonbinary, and 6.67% as N/A.
60% of funded students were from the USA (and NSF funds were only used
for US students).  In 2017, 24% of funded students self-reported as
women, so 2018 represented a signficant improvement.  None of the
scholarship recipients had previously been awarded support to attend a
PLMW.

The program consisted of technical talks, mentoring talks, a social
event, and a panel discussion.  Speakers represented a diverse
collection of international researchers from both industry and
academia, with a wide range of seniority.  Of the technical and
mentoring talks, 62.5% of the speakers were women or members of
underrepresented minorities.  To reach a broader audience beyond the
in-person attendees, the program was video-recorded and made available
online.

In sum, the PLMW @ ICFP 2018 project was successful in cultivating a
new cohort of future programming languages researchers.  Scholarships
were awarded to a diverse range of students, who were able to attend a
mentoring worskshop with technical and career-oriented talks.  They
socialized with eachother and accomplished academic and industrial
researchers.  Participants also were able to attend one of the premier
research conference in programming languages: ICFP.
